The Last horse is Salesforce- They don't have the best models, and they do not have the organization's tentacles into its data as Microsoft does. Still, Salesforce is what the CEO uses to track his revenue and everyone on the outside of the big three has integration for it. Benoit can't help taking potshots at Microsoft, but they share many of the same huge customers so what's the endgame here? Half a horse.

Oh, wait --- Everyone else! Amazon is super quiet on this front. The future of many smaller models can't be discounted.

In case you were wondering who the partial horses are here, to me it:

* OpenAI  - a full horse in influence, if not ability.

* Microsoft (Consumer) - A half-horse that is struggling to get out the door because IT departments everywhere are super queasy about the notion of unlocking the desktop to the panopticon model (at least a model that is off-prem and not owned by the business).

* Microsoft - (Enterprise) a 75% horse that seemingly is ready to capitalize! They can use the popular models, the custom models, Purview permissions, and Fabric insights and can define your custom prompts and share them across your organization. 

The problem is that all this drags down the raw quality of the OpenAI models. It's increasingly harder to explain how generated AI quality is worse versus naive testing with a GPT Pro account. Its even harder to determine what steps are being done to improve it.

Their biggest assumption here is that public and localized viewer data is important enough in the early days. Like most of their AI products, historically, they leave most of the customization and business logic framing to their customers to build out. 

It will be interesting to see who, if any, platforms or customers can get something for the market with this generation of agent tooling.

I think that's kind of the thing that sinks a lot of chatbot projects, in that you want to do so many things, you never nail any one specific thing.

The first unhappy path I build is the escalation fallback - You have to divert to a proven support channel until you handle all the messy interactions, and then slowly whittle away at the cases based on severity where that is necessary. And know you will never handle every edge.

Lastly, there is a small talk path. I'm not a huge fan of telling jokes or things like that unless you have dedicated content resources to keep this line of conversation fresh. But a well-timed joke can be super delightful. Just don't turn your bot in a Micheal Scott-type that drives a joke into the ground via repetition or trying to land a funny in an inappropriate situation.¬†
For me, I start with the error handling. The one thing people attribute to \dumb machines\" is very precise input requirements. If a bot cannot do a thing
column4: being able to say \"I'm sorry I do not know how to do that
column5: but I CAN help you with topic x\" is a very human way of glossing over knowledge gaps. Have some sort of escalation path for situations like this can also improve the experience.

Link: which is very hard to do on a personal level but easily mocked using strong conception of the user story. For example
Message: a bot can be designed to help a user troubleshoot their email
column4: but a user might actually have a problem with their computer.¬†

Date: Being able to support the issue
Link: acknowledge what it clearly can't and cannot do
Message: and offer some sort of actionable advice even on non-domain topics are all checkpoints on the way to being \"more human\"."
